 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
investment  in  compulsory  convertible  debentures  (CCDs)  issued  by  KUL  Urban  Development 
Private Limited  (KUL UDPL) in an amount up to the rupee equivalent of $35,000,000 for Phase 2 
of the Pune Nirvana Hills Slum Rehabilitation Project in India.  

 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Project Identification and Description 

1. 

Project Identification 

2. 
India suffers from an acute shortage of housing, estimated at 24.71 million housing units, 
and Maharashtra has the greatest shortage at 3.72 million units.1 The problem will increase due 
to  rapid  urbanization  and  population  growth,  amongst  other  factors.  Given  this  tremendous 
shortage  of  housing,  substandard  housing  and  slums  are  proliferating.  The  Asian  Development 
Bank (ADB) was approached by Deutsche Bank, a leading real estate financing bank in India, to 
provide  financing  for  this  slum  rehabilitation  project.  The  project  is  considered  to  be  one  of  the 
best  opportunities  for  ADB  to  support  slum  rehabilitation  because  of  its  good  location,  high 
development impact, and strong sponsor, Kumar Urban Development Limited (KUDL).   

2. 

Project Design 

Pune,  the  second-largest  city  in  Maharashtra,  has  a  population  of  approximately  5.5 
3. 
million people, of which about 32.5% to 40% live in slums.2 It is a growing information technology 
and manufacturing (primarily automobiles) center approximately 170 kilometers east of Mumbai. 
The city also has an abundance of universities. The project is situated on a prime  piece of real 
estate,  advantageously  located  in  the  Kothrud  area  of  southwest  Pune,  near  the  Pune–Mumbai 
expressway, airport (within 15 kilometers), information technology centers, and major universities. 
Residential housing  is  in  short  supply  across  the  city  and  in  particular  in  the  Kothrud  area.  The 
project represents one of a few new developments in Kothrud, which also suffers from a lack of 
retail and office space.  

4. 
The project covers a site of 76 acres and entails the in-situ rehabilitation of slum dwellings 
and  the  development  of  mixed-use  residential  and  office  and  retail  space,  which  the  sponsor  is 
entitled  to  sell  at  market  prices.  Currently  a  large  number  of  slum  households  are  living  in  sub-
standard  conditions  on the  site.  The  sponsor will  construct  (i)  multiple  buildings  to  re-house  the 
slum dwellers, each building with 11 floors of 13 units each, and several commercial spaces for 
small  businesses  that  are  operating  in  the  slum  area;  (ii) residential  buildings  with  apartments, 
office space, and retail space; and (iii) amenities and infrastructure for the use of the re-housed 
slum  dwellers—housing  society  offices,  a  self-employment  center  for  women,  playgrounds, 
daycare  facilities,  community  and  senior  citizen  recreation  centers,  libraries,  a  primary  and 
secondary school, and a park.  

5. 
The  project  is  expected  to  be  constructed  in  7  years,  including  a  4-year  construction 
period  for  the  rehabilitation  buildings  that  started  in  2011.  A  phased  approach  is  being  used  to 
manage  the  construction  and  regulatory  approval  process  and  to  minimize  the  need  for  transit 
housing.  During  construction,  the  slum  dwellers  will  either be  moved  into  temporary  housing  on

 2  

 

the  site  or  be  paid  a  monthly  rental  allowance  until  they  are  moved  into  their  new,  permanent 
housing.  Additionally,  for  eligible  and  ineligible  slum  dwellers  under  the  SRS  (para. 6),  the 
developer  will  pay  a  moving  allowance  before  the  slum  dwellers  vacate  their  homes,  and  when 
the  slum  dwellers  move  into  their  new  apartments.  The  architect  of  the  commercially  saleable 
portion of the project (the “free-sale” area) is P.G. Patki Architects Pvt. Ltd., which has designed 
several well-known projects in India. 

6.  
The SRS, regulated by the Slum Rehabilitation Authority (SRA), is an innovative program 
that  was  introduced  by  the  state  of  Maharashtra  to  deal  with  rapidly  growing  slums  by 
incentivizing  the  private  sector  to  fund  their  rehabilitation.  Under  the  SRS,  developers  construct 
new,  free  residential  buildings  on  a  slum  site  and  give  eligible  slum  dwellers  title  to  and  full 
ownership of their new apartments. Eligibility is determined by the SRA and is based upon proof 
of existence of the slum structure since 1995 and residence for one year prior to the rehabilitation. 
In return for the development of the new buildings for the slum dwellers, rights are granted to the 
developers to develop a portion of slum land for commercial development purposes, based on the 
floor space index determined by the SRA.3 Thus, for every one square foot of new housing that a 
developer provides to a slum dweller, the developer is entitled to 2.5 ft2–3 ft2 (depending on slum 
density  and  size)  for  the  development  of  a  free-sale  area.  Under  the  SRS,  each  eligible  slum 
household receives ownership of a 269 ft2 apartment with a kitchen, bathroom with toilet, running 
water,  and  electricity,  which  is  a  vast  improvement  over  current  conditions  in  the  slums. 
Ownership  of  the  apartment  must  be  maintained  for  10 years,  after  which  it  becomes  freely 
transferable. Slum dwellers who currently have shops are provided space on the lower levels of 
the new buildings. The size of this space will be equal to their current shops, but cannot exceed 
269 ft2. 

7. 
Operation  and  maintenance  of  the  rehabilitation  buildings  is  carried  out  by  the  housing 
society,  formed  by  the  apartment  owners,  which  will  outsource  such  work  to  external  parties. 4 
The sponsor will deposit a fixed amount per slum household in an escrow account, which is jointly 
managed  by  the  SRA  and  the  housing  society.  Interest  earned  from  this  is  expected  to  be 
sufficient to cover such costs. The households pay their own monthly electricity and running-water 
costs. These costs are expected to be relatively low and, in many cases, are already being borne 
by the households.5  

3. 

The Sponsor 

8. 
Established in 1993 by Mr. Lalit Kumar Jain, chairman and managing director, the sponsor 
is  a  leading  real  estate development  company  based  in  Pune,.  Mr.  Kumar  and  his  family  jointly 
hold 100% of KUDL. KUDL also has operations in Mumbai and Bangalore. Mr. Jain is well known 
in the real estate industry in Pune and is also the current national president of the Confederation 
of Real Estate Developers Association of India. KUDL has garnered several awards, including a 
listing in 2009 in the top 10 developers in India by Construction World magazine. KUDL is an ISO 
9001:2000  (for  quality  management  system),  an  ISO  14001:2004  (for  environment)  and  an 
OHSAS-18000 (certification for occupational health and safety assessment series) company.  

                                                 
3   Commercial  development  rights  can  also  be  in  the  form  of  transferable  development  rights,  which  can  be  used  to 

build saleable area outside the slum project area. 

4   Housing societies are common in India. The title to an entire multi-owner site and building is held by a cooperative 
housing society  whose shareholders are the individual apartment owners. Ownership of an apartment is passed to 
the individual apartment owner via shares in each society, which give the owner exclusive rights to use a particular 
apartment. Property is sold by transfer of the shares with their appurtenant rights.  

5   The  developer  estimates  that  the  slum  dwellers  currently  spend  Rs500–Rs600  per  month  per  household  for 

electricity, and Rs1,400 annually for water and property taxes. 

 KUDL’s  real  estate  developments  cater  to  a  wide  variety  of  customers  and  can  be 
9. 
segregated  into  the  following  categories:  residential  (which  comprises  about  80%  of  the 
company’s  developments);  integrated  townships;  redevelopment  projects;  slum  rehabilitation; 
special  economic  zones;  and  commercial  (office  and  retail)  projects.  KUDL  has  completed  3.5 
million  ft2  of  developable  area  since  2006,  including  14  residential  (of  which  three  are 
redevelopments) and seven commercial projects. Several projects are ongoing in various stages 
across five cities, including Mumbai, and Kumar’s share of the saleable area totals 38.89 million 
ft2  for  residential  and  9.05  million  ft2  for  office and  retail  space.  The  project  is  a  high  priority  for 
KUDL  and  the  developer  is  hopeful  that  it  will  be  a  benchmark  for  future  slum  rehabilitation 
projects.  

B. 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

1. 

Impact 

10. 
The  development  impact  of  the  project  will  be  high.  It  provides  a  sustainable  and 
innovative  solution  to  the  particularly  challenging  and  intractable  problem  of  rehabilitating  urban 
slums, and concurrently increases housing stock for a growing urban population. Given the high 
number of urban slums in Asia, this is a critical issue for ADB. The project will serve to decrease 
the  number  of  slums  where  a  large  proportion  of  Pune’s  inhabitants  live,  and  increase  private 
sector participation in replacing slums with better housing. The project is one of the larger slum 
rehabilitation  projects  in  Pune  and  KUDL  is  also  a  well–known  developer;  hence,  it  is  expected 
that  the  success  of  the  project  will  provide  a  template  that  can  be  replicated  by  other  projects. 
Finally, the project will support the development of office and retail space in Pune.  

2. 

Outcome 

11. 
The  project's  primary  outcome  will  be  an  improvement  in  the  quality  of  life  for  slum 
dwellers and access to more housing for urban dwellers in Pune. This is an important contribution 
to the lives of these slum dwellers, who will benefit from the provision of sanitation, clean drinking 
water, and stronger and safer shelter. This is directly supportive of Millennium Development Goal 
7  (ensuring  environmental  sustainability).  For  most  of  these  families;  obtaining  a  title  to  an 
apartment  will  most  probably  represent  ownership  of  their  first,  large  valuable  asset.  Gender 
equality  and  empowerment  of  women  is  supported  through  (i) 100%  issuance  of  joint  titles  to 
husbands  and  wives;  (ii)  100%  issuance  of  titles  to  women  who  head  households;  and  (iii)  a 
requirement for a minimum of 33% representation of women in the housing society. The project’s 
provision  of  safe  and  secure  housing,  as  well  as  other  facilities  such  as  playgrounds,  daycare 
facilities and schools, is especially beneficial for women and children.  

12. 
For  the  non-slum  urban  dwellers  of  Pune,  the  shortage  of  housing  in  the  city  will  be 
partially  mitigated  through  the  project  by  creating  access  to  housing  for  about  9,000  people  as 
well as office and retail space. Construction is a large contributor to employment,  particularly in 
the  form  of  semiskilled  and  unskilled  jobs  for  lower  income  groups.  Skills  and  entrepreneurship 
training for women will also be conducted. Increasing the share of women employed in the non-
agriculture  wage  sector  contributes  directly  to  the  Millennium  Development  Goal  3  (promote 
gender  equality  and  empower  women).  After  construction,  300–500  jobs  will  be  created  as  a 
result of ongoing retail and other commercial operations in the redeveloped area, of which at least 
20% will be for women.  

 

 

3 

 

 4  

 

3. 

Outputs 

13. 
The  outputs  include  construction  of  multiple  rehabilitation  buildings,  providing  new  and 
better  housing  facilities  for  current  slum  dwellers;  free-sale  apartments;  retail  space;  and  office 
and retail space. Currently, an average of 150 workers are on-site each day, which will gradually 
increase to 1,000 workers on-site per day at the peak of construction in 2014–2015. The project 
will also generate substantial employment for unskilled workers during construction (estimated at 
60%–70%  of  the  total  construction  jobs).  Moreover,  30%  of  the  total  jobs  for  interior  works  are 
targeted  for  women.  In  addition,  the  project  will  contribute  to  the  local  economy  through  the 
purchase of local goods and services. Finally, the sponsor will benefit from better environmental 
and social standards through implementation of and adherence to ADB’s social safeguards and 
the gender action plan.  

C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020  

14. 
The  project  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2020,  which  promotes  private  sector 
investment  in  the  infrastructure  sector,  as  well  as  an  improvement  in  public  health  standards.6 
Strategy  2020  also  states  that  ADB  will  continue  to  emphasize  gender  equality  and  the 
empowerment  of  women  as  fundamental  elements  of  achieving  inclusive  growth.  The  project  is 
expected to yield tangible benefits for women and empower them, e.g., through joint ownership of 
apartments  and  job  and  skills  training.  Also,  under  Strategy  2020,  cities  constitute  a  key  focus, 
specifically in terms of promoting livable cities that are socially inclusive. The project promotes, in 
an inclusive and innovative way, the private sector’s participation in the slum rehabilitation sector.  
This is a sector which the government has so far and can be expected to support only to a limited 
extent.    

2. 

Consistency with Country and Sector Strategy  

The project is consistent with the country partnership strategy (CPS) 2009–2012 for India.7 
15. 
The  CPS  aims  to  significantly  strengthen  ADB’s  infrastructure  activities  and  to  encourage 
innovative  financing.  The  CPS  further  notes  that  ADB’s  ongoing  urban  sector  operations  will 
combine  infrastructure  development  with  targeted  poverty  reduction  components.  Finally,  the 
project  is  in  line  with  ADB’s  desire  to  undertake  projects  that  have  targeted  poverty  reduction 
components  and  promote  inclusive  growth.  The  project  is  also  consistent  with  ADB’s  strategies 
and  plans  for  private  sector  development, 8  poverty  reduction, 9  and  urban  operations. 10  The 
poverty  reduction  strategy  supports  the  need  to  undertake  sustainable  housing  projects 
implemented by the private sector. ADB’s draft urban operations plan states that ADB’s support 
for  inclusive  cities  must  include  support  to  slum  upgrading,  housing,  land  tenure,  and 
development and housing finance.

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

18. 
ADB  proposes  to  provide  the  rupee  equivalent  of  up  to  $35  million  to  the  project  in  the 
form of CCDs, which will be issued by KUL UDPL (issuer). CCDs have been used in the past by 
foreign investors for slum rehabilitation projects, as well as for projects in other sectors. 

19. 
The  issuer  is  expected  to  pay  to  ADB  and  other  CCD  holders  a  fixed  coupon  amount, 
payable quarterly. ADB is expected to have the right to nominate one director for appointment to 
the board of the issuer. To facilitate exit arrangements, ADB will grant to the sponsor a call option 
under which it will have an option to buy the CCDs, or on default, for a predetermined amount that 
would both pay the amount invested by ADB and provide a return on such investment. Should the 
sponsor not exercise the option, the CCDs will automatically convert to shares of the issuer. The 
CCD investors may also force a conversion if the issuer defaults on its CCD obligations.  

20. 
Security.  The  OPCD  loan  from  the  issuer  to  the  project  company  will  be  secured  by  a 
mortgage on land and buildings of the project at a minimum collateral value  in relation to the loan 
amount.    Additional  collateral  satisfactory  to  the  CCD  holders  will  be  provided  if  the  collateral 
value declines below a certain level. The value of the collateral will be reviewed on a semiannual 
basis by an internationally recognized independent real estate company and valuator. In addition, 
the OPCD loan will be secured by a guarantee from the sponsor. All proceeds in an enforcement 
scenario  will  be  shared  pari  passu  among  Deutsche  Bank,  the  NCD  holders,  and  the  OPCD 
holders.  In  an  enforcement  situation,  conversion  to  shares  will  thus  give  the  CCD  holders  the

necessary, to (i) exercise the security for the OPCD loan and (ii) call on the sponsor guarantee. In 
certain  circumstances,  control  of  the  issuer  may  also  enable  the  investors  to  recover  their

B. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

21. 

ADB’s value addition to the project is expected to be the following: 

(i) 

(ii) 

Funding for the real estate sector, particularly for slum rehabilitation projects, is not 
readily  available  from  commercial  banks.  The  project  will  play  a  pioneering  role  in 
demonstrating  the  commercial  viability  of  slum  rehabilitation  projects  undertaken 
through the SRS in India, which may help to catalyze commercial bank financing for 
future slum rehabilitation projects.  

ADB’s  participation  will  further  strengthen  the  project  through  the  application  of 
ADB’s  social  safeguards,  gender  and  development  targets,  and  environmental 
standards, which are of particular importance.  

C. 

Risks 

22. 
Real  estate  market  risk.  The  project  is  exposed  to  real  estate  market  risk,  which  is 
subject to high volatility. The current outlook for the Indian residential real estate market overall 
has  been  uncertain  and  opinions  have  generally  been  cautious,  particularly  in  areas  that  have 
been the subject of speculative bubbles.  Downward movements in the real estate sector could 
have  a  negative  impact  on  the  success  of  the  project,  as  well  as  the  sponsor’s  ongoing 
developments.    However,  the  real  estate  market  in  Pune  has  been  stable  from  about  2005  to 
2011.    Market  risk  is  mitigated  since  the  project  is  located  in  what  is  considered  a  highly 
desirable location in Pune, with strong cash flows from the sales of residential space and rental 
of  office  and  retail  space.  Additionally,  the  requirement  that  the  OPCD  loan  maintain  a  certain 
collateral  cover,  which  will  be  provided  from  non-project  sources  if  needed,  protects  ADB’s 
position in the event of declines in market value of the project itself. 

23.   Project  risk.    The  project’s  cash  flow  is  vulnerable  to  increases  in  construction  costs, 
sales price, construction delays and slowdowns in sales booking rates.  If cash flows fall below 
projections, the company’s ability to service its debts and complete the project on time may be 
severely affected.  This risk is partially mitigated by KUDL’s corporate guarantee covering debt 
service and project completion, a significant amount of sponsor equity to be infused, and sizable 
revenues  which  accrue  from  year  six  onwards  from  the  sale  of  residential  units  and  rentals  of 
retail space.  

24.   Sponsor  risk.    Sponsor  cash  flows  are  dependent  on  stable  real  estate  market 
conditions  and 
timely  and  successful  execution  of  ongoing  and  pipeline  real  estate 
developments.  This is also the first time that the sponsor will be engaging in large scale slum 
rehabilitation,  which  raises  some  concerns  on  its  ability  to  undertake  the  project,  including 
resettlement of the slum dwellers.  However, comfort is drawn from the fact that KUDL has over 
40 years  of  experience  in  real  estate  development,  primarily  in  the  Pune  market,  where  the 
project  is  based,  and  has  successfully  developed  over  10  million  ft2  of  commercial  and 
residential  areas.  KUDL  is  very  committed  to  the  success  of  the  project,  which  it  aspires  to 
establish as the benchmark for slum rehabilitation projects in India.   

 Social safeguards risk. Resettlement is the main risk and the most important element of 
25. 
any  slum  rehabilitation  project.  Resettlement  will  be  largely  voluntary  since  70%  of  the  slum 
households  have  given  their  consent,  as  required  by  the  SRS.  Furthermore,  when  eligibility  for 
new  housing  is  determined  by  the  SRA,  individual  agreements  will  be  signed  with  the  slum 
dwellers. The in-situ resettlement will comply with the rules and regulations of the SRA and any 
involuntary  resettlement  will  meet  ADB  safeguard  standards.  Due  diligence  has  confirmed  that 
adequate  social  safeguards  are  in  place,  and  ADB  and  an  external  expert  will  carefully  monitor 
the project during implementation.  

26. 
Regulation  risk.  The  SRA  approval  process  can  be  lengthy.  As  slum  rehabilitation 
continues to grow and develop, it is possible that existing regulations may change. The regulatory 
risk is mitigated in that the sponsor has already received the significant approvals required for this 
project.  Progress of further approvals is proceeding satisfactorily and will be monitored. 

27. 
 Reputational risk. Slum rehabilitation is a complex process with sensitive social issues. If 
improperly  implemented,  the  project  could  create  reputational  risk  for  ADB  due  to,  for  instance, 
discontent  with  the  quality  of  construction,  delays  in  completion  of  the  project,  political 
interference, allegations of misconduct, mishandling of involuntary resettlement, and fabrication of 
eligibility.  Additionally,  the  real  estate  development  and  construction  sectors  generally  pose 
heightened  risks  for  fraud  and  corruption.  These  risks  are  partly  mitigated  by  the  social 
safeguards that are in place, as noted above, and through oversight of the SRA. ADB will closely 
monitor these issues throughout the project. 

28. 
 Corporate  governance  risk.  The  company  is  a  family  business,  as  is  common  in  the 
Indian real estate sector. ADB, as well as its cofinanciers, have done due diligence on this issue 
and this risk is deemed to be acceptable and mitigated to some extent by appropriate corporate 
governance  in  the  form  of  formal  board  committees  modeled  on  the  Securities  and  Exchange 
Board  of  India’s  regulations,  such  as  an  audit  committee,  a  shareholders’  and  investors’ 
grievance committee, a finance committee, and the presence of independent board members. 

A.   

Safeguards and Social Dimensions  

IV. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

29. 
Safeguards.  The  project  is  classified  as  category  B  for  environment,  category  A  for 
involuntary resettlement, and category C for indigenous peoples. The potential environmental and 
social impacts and risks of the project have been defined in the environmental and social impact 
assessment,  and  effective  measures  to  manage  the  impacts  are  outlined  in  the  environmental 
and social management plan. The sponsor has prepared a rehabilitation action plan to minimize 
these impacts.  The institutional capacity and commitment of the sponsor to manage the project’s 
social and environmental risks are deemed adequate. The sponsor obtained the consent of 70% 
of the slum dwellers in the buildable areas, which, as noted, is a condition to SRA approval. The 
sponsor has a dedicated community relations team to ensure that concerns are heard and dealt 
with adequately. From 2004 to 2011, at least 12 major consultation activities occurred and nearly 
all slum dwellers in the area participated. Information billboards, a model unit, and an information 
center have also been established to increase awareness of the project. 

30.  Other  social  dimensions. The project is categorized as effective gender mainstreaming 
because it provides security of tenure and housing titles to both men and women slum dwellers. A 
gender action plan has been prepared that includes issuance of joint ownership certificates under 
the  names  of  wife  and  husband,  and  of  sole  ownership  certificates  to  women  who  head 
households;  33%  representation  and  active  involvement  of  women  in  the  housing  societies; 

7 

 

 8  

 

women’s  skills  enhancement  and  livelihood  development  through  self-help  groups  supported by 
civil society organizations; and recruiting of at least 33% female community liaison officers for the 
sponsor’s  community  relations  team  to  ensure  gender-responsive  community  engagement.  The 
project  will  also  provide  vital  infrastructure  such  as  daycare  facilities,  a  primary  and  secondary 
school,  water  and  sanitation,  and  power  connections,  which  will  particularly  benefit  women.  A 
labor  management  plan  has  been  prepared  to  manage  issues  related  to  migrant  labor  and  to 
ensure that KUDL, its contractors, and subcontractors comply with national labor regulations and 
the internationally accepted core labor standards.  

B. 

Anticorruption Policy 

31. 
KUDL  and  KUL  UDPL  were  advised  of  ADB’s  policy  implementing  best  international 
practice relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB 
will  ensure  that  the  investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting 
corruption,  money  laundering,  financing  of  terrorism,  and  remedies  for  ADB  in  the  event  of 
noncompliance.  

C. 

Investment Limitations  

32. 
The project is within ADB’s approved medium-term, country, industry, and group exposure 
limits. ADB’s investment is an equity investment for the purposes of Indian law.  ADB ownership 
upon conversion, however, will be subject to limits on control in favor of the other CCD holders 
and other investors.
